column2: 35-44 on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$4$I have been taking a generic version of Klonopin for 5 years now. At first I took it every day at 1mg doses for the first 6 months. Now only take it when I need it at 0.5mg's. It works great for general anxiety. If you have something such as a major fear of public speaking its not going to kill that anxiety 100 % by itself. Consider taking it with Propranolol. That combination is a miracle worker. But as far as just general anxiety goes Klonopin by itself is great. I've never really had any major withdraw side effects with it but then I'm at a small dose anyways. When I'm taking it I feel really at ease with my thoughts and others around. If you take this please don't be a jerk while taking it. Enjoy the fact your finally not anxious for once and at peace. Some people use it as an excuse to act stupid or annoying. Sure your going to feel nice while your taking it but don't be 'that guy' and give people a bad reputation that need to take it to function normally. You are still in control and your not drunk so be responsible.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $2$1$4$Klonopin is the least benzodiazepine of the benzodiazpines. Please understand that now. Chemically speaking it's just barely a benzo. When I was first prescribed this it was a direct switch from Xanax. Well...that didn't go over too well! Went into extreme Xanax withdrawals
column3: I was sweating so hard (and shaking) that it frightened me - Klonopin was a poor direct replacement for Xanax. I came to learn that Klonopin simply doesn't share all the characteristics of other benzodiazepines. People need to know this upfront
column4: lest they find it out the hard way. The only plus
column5: perhaps
column6: is that Klonopin doesn't have a strongly sedating component. So it might be useful for those wanting to maintain 100% alertness during the day. That's about it. Common side effects characteristic of Klonopin: very glassy eyes and a distinct change in behavior. Me
column7: I became too 'outspoken' while on it. And not in a good way.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$1$1$"For those people that seem to have an attitude about why Klonopin has worked for them
column3: why they take it
column4: etc.
column5: I say good for you and your attitude
column6: and lack of knowledge and/or withdrawal experience.  The worst is yet to come.

column2: was amazed at how awesome I was and felt when I started taking it.  There's no question Klonopin works very well. It just works too well...until the dosage isn't enough. It's not that it stops working on your brain
column3: it just becomes confusing to the patient because old symptoms start to re-appear. It's still breaking through the blood brain barrier and shutting down/taking over your Gaba receptors though. The problem is
column4: the brain has now begun to rely on the drug instead of its own calming mechanism
column5: so it needs more. Most Drs just up the dose
column6: which only makes the brain more dependent
column7: shutting down more receptors.

column1: Klonopin was never intended as a drug to be taken long term
column2: for very good reason.

column1: I ended up in the emergency room 4 different times b/c I was in tolerance withdrawal. I didn't know I was
column2: until the 4th ER visit to a different hospital. The dr was smart enough to know
column3: to tell me and to contact my dr. That was over a year ago and I've been tapering since then. It's been a roller coaster but nothing compared to now
column4: as I'm at .25mg pills that I'm slowly cutting down each week.

column1: There's no way to explain the withdrawals. Ive always kept my body as healthy and strong as possible
column2: but this little pill is a ticket to hell. Ive suffered so many grand mal seizures but I'd rather deal with the seizures
column3: than go thru this hell again.

column1: I have zero respect for anyone associated with delving this poison out.  Honestly
column2: you are all satan's little helpers.

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I am a 47 year old Male and have been on antidepressants for over 25 years. I have tried many different drugs.  I suffered horribly with thoughts of suicide on a daily bases I hated those feelings!! I didn't want my family to think that I was a quitter so I pushed through those thoughts everyday! Klonopin was suggested by a friend who had a bottle of pills they had stopped taking. I took .5 mg a day for the first week and my thoughts of suicide faded away I went to my doctor who had me on Wellbutrin 3 pills a day he told me to keep taking the klonopin at .5mg a day along with the Wellbutrin. I have taken the same dose for a year and a half and still feel great no thoughts of suicide. Side effects
column3: makes me sleepy but if I get out of bed and stay active that feeling diminishes.  I personally would have to say that klonopin has saved my life. 8/14

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$4$I am writing this post to warn all who are interested in taking any benzodiazepan - they can be extremely helpful but are incredibly physically addictive and often times your GP or prescribing physician does not inform you of that.  I was taking Klonopin once a day at 1 MG for about 4 months and then I leaned how addictive it was and stopped cold turkey.  My mistake - I narrowly avoided having a seizure and didn't sleep for almost a week or eat or anything due to the withdrawal.  I went back to taking them and had a psychiatist wean me off of them
column3: and I still experienced withdrawal symptons though not as bad.  So
column4: please be careful
column5: only take it when you need it
column6: and consult with a physician when you choose to stop taking it.  I am currently taking it again - though only as needed
column7: and no more than 3 times a week - because life stressors have been more than I can handle lately.  So
column8: just please be careful with this drug
column9: it can be so helpful but in the long run the cure may be worse than the cause.

I have no trouble recommending this drug.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I had been diagnosed with acute anxiety disorder in my early 20's (I'm now almost 40). In my opinion I would rate Klonopin at the top of all benzodiazepines (and i've tried almost all of them) as it has a relatively long half-life (lasts longer than most benzos). I have been taking .25mg (1/2 of a .5mg tablet) daily for nearly a decade now
column3: and I have had no urge or need to increase my dosage (although it does take discipline to take the absolutely smallest effective amount without wanting to experiment with more).  This dosage
column4: combined with regular cardio excercise
column5: has eliminated what was once extreme debilitating panic/anxiety.  If you're going to start this medication
column6: take small amounts (experiment with the smallest dosage possible that still remedies your anxiety
column7: etc).  Don't ever get into the habit of taking more
column8: and stay indifferent to people
column9: doctors
column10: the media
column11: etc
column12: who criticize the use of this medication. Become comfortable with the likelihood that you may need to take this medication permanently. In other words
column13: if you maintain a small daily dose regimin
column14: there's no need to put yourself through the pain of ceasing the use of this wonderful medication. I am certain it is much more harmful to stop taking this medication than it would be to continue to use it responsibly for a life-time.

102$Condition: A Feeling of Restlessness with Inability to Sit Still$9/18/2013 4:28:19 PM$Reviewer: Bridget, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$For years I refused most meds but was given klonipin along with an ssri 3 years ago...should have tried earlier....works like a charm for me.  Took it as prescribed and felt for once in my life balanced and even tempered...helped with so many of my other conditions as well, gi problems, etc.  Only went off once suddenly because I had a back injury and didn't want to take pain meds with klonipin...never do that again!!! Much healthier for me to NOT take pain meds but stay on klonipin...during most of the year I have lessened the dosage to 1 1/2 tabs per day ....taken 1/2 3pm, and 1 at bedtime.  I cannot take other meds like elavil or nortriptolene ...those make me jump out of my skin and turn me severely depressed.  Have never felt like jumping off a high deck but elavil and nortriptolene did!!! It's all blood chemistry and you must work closely with your health care provider at all times.  Klonipin works wonders for me.  Also be careful though with mixing it with any other drugs...look at the ingredients and any contraindications,

106$Condition: Panic Disorder$8/18/2013 3:30:11 PM$Reviewer: Coopers, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$I know they say mood drugs affect people differently,  but the effects of this drug were very frightening to me. I took it for 3 weeks at 1mg per day and I felt like I lost 3 weeks of my life... as in I remembered it happening, but didn't feel like I was even there. I quit my job, I got pulled over for driving erratically and I cried every night. I felt like there was no way out, and my husband asked me to stop the medication and call my doctor immediately. I hadn't talked to most of my friends, but the one I did told me something hadn't been right but she didn't know what. I've never lost hope like that before. I talked to the magistrate about the ticket I received,  got a note fromy doctor... but it turns out the magistrate didn't even need it. He said he was very familiar with the drug and implied that he wished it weren't even on the market. The only other stories I have heard directly from people are similar if not so severe. The drug even earned a comment on 'Silver Linings Playbook.' I am terrified of this drug, and what it could do to other people out there. Maybe it works for some, but as with any mood drug please me extra careful. I am now on Depakote for mood instead and my anxiety has subsided. Also consider a good therapist before messing around with this stuff.

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$5$5$"Prescribed for my chronic anxiety to use as needed.  Feel a light buzz at 1mg shortly after taking it but nothing else.  At 2mg my anxiety begins to get reduced and mood is slightly boosted and every milligram above that reduces my anxiety accordingly but doesn't make me any more euphoric than the 2mg dose.  Mood and anxiety are affected 30 minutes after dosing. Drowsiness kicks in a few hours after dosing.  Memory and cognitive impairment can begin on as low as a 3mg dosage for me since I have little benzodiazepine tolerance built up.  Doses above 3mg
column3: watch out.  Blackoutland and confusion while blacking out (I recorded myself).  Too bad
column4: because my anxiety was actually manageable for those 12 or 24 hours after dosing.  I settle for 2mg doses.  This way I avoid most of the drowsiness and avoid cognitive and memory impairment while getting to feel a slight mood boost and some anxiety relief.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$3$1$Benzo's are heaven/hell drugs. They are extremely effective in controlling anxiety and panic disorders. They are also extremely addictive. Doctor's like Klonopin because it has a long half-life. Apparently
column3: some people do have a body chemistry that keeps them from getting addicted
column4: or it could be how they take the medication. I have been on Benzo's 19 years. I have CFS. I tried an adrenal supplement for it and it caused the panic disorder. So at age 34 I was put on Benzo's. I'm almost 54 now. The addiction started around the one-year mark. It nearly killed me. Now I wear 2 watches so I can take my morning and evening dose to the second. My body is synchronized to a 3rd watch that I don't set the alarm on so I won't run down the battery. That is the one I take my pills by. Also
column5: because each pill is a different weight I bought a precision scale and I file each pill down to the same weight. But each batch of the drug has a different amount of medicine in it so some months I'd start feeling sick and I had to increase my dose ever so slightly using the scale. AND
column6: pharmacies like to change the brand you're on so that has been a battle. I had a close friend who committed suicide because of her Klonopin addiction. She was an OB/GYN nurse
column7: with CFS. That was about 15 years ago. Now
column8: I'm taking care of my elderly mother who lives with me and still managing my addiction (with the help of a wonderful and very understanding psychiatrist). Oh
column9: my dose is 1mg twice a day. I hope this will help someone. Good luck and be careful.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Klonopin has completely alleviated my symptoms of essential tremor.  I am currently taking 2mg twice a day.  I lived with this embarrassing condition for 20* years.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$highly effective. ONLY for occasional or short term use!  All benzos are highly addictive and effects will wear off requiring higher and higher dosages to maintain desired effects.  Anziety snd/or panic attacks will disapper immediately if you have never used benzos before.  Alcoholics or recovering acohol/drug addicts should only used under physician monitored dosage.  Exceedeing prescribed dosage will result in extreme sleepiness and further the development of addicton.  Withdrawal symptoms mild compared to aocohol or opiates
column3: but if you stop abruptly you will feel highly agitated and will not be able to sleep for several days.  Very useful when needed but long term everyday use may cause more problems than origianl issue drug prescribed for.  Mixing with alcohol or other tranquilizers will cause euphoria followed by deep sleep and can be lethal.

And I always took the med as prescribed, no substance abuse! its just the way the med is. It is addicting physiologically. Be careful! column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$4$4$I have been on Klonopin for 25 years.  It usually reduces my tics.  They do increase with stress and Klonopin causes sexual problems including ED.  However other ED medications
column3: both RX and especially certain herbal found on 'Better Sex Mall' conteract the sexual side affects.  I change dosage between 1 to 2 mg per day and occasionally discontinue for short times without any withdrawal or rebound.  For me all of the side effects expounded have not been a problem.  I have had Tourette syndrome since age 9 or 10 and I'm now 71.  This has been a miracle drug for me and should be given a good try under a physician's care before dismissing it because of all the warnings and expressed side effects.  I am not addicted to it even after 25 years of use.

55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$I was prescribed Klonopin for anxiety.  Within a month
column3: it stopped working.  I built a tolerance to the drug.  What I DID not know was that the drug is HIGHLY physically addictive.  I spoke to a Neurologist who told me that is as addictive as heroin or alcohol.  She told me that it is VERY dangerous to withdraw from Klonopin suddenly. She gave me a slow taper schedule
column4: but it was VERY difficult.  I experienced tremors
column5: nausea
column6: and sweats during the withdrawal period.  After the last does
column7: it took 35 hours to completely leave my system...and the anxiety came back with a vengeance.  This drug should only be used for a very short time.  In my opinion
column8: Klonopin should have a black box warning on the label.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$3$3$"When I was a little girl
column3: my mother has ""agoriphobia"" and
column4: for a time
column5: she would never leave the house. I swore I would never be like that. I thought she should just get over it and I was a little embarrassed by her ""illness."" But one day I was driving with my two children in the car
column6: and out of the blue I had this sense of impending doom
column7: my heart was slamming in my chest
column8: and I was terrified that I would die behind the wheel and my children would die in a subsequent car crash.  I went to see a doctor who
column9: luckily
column10: had some training in the signs of hormonal imbalance and a LOT more compassion than I showed my mom.  I was diagnosed as being peri-menopausal. Klonopin was the first stop-gap for me - it saved me from becoming a prisoner in my home
column11: as my mom had been.  It also helped me help HER discover that this was a medical disorder
column12: not a mental one.(I still feel guilty for how I treated her.)  That helped HER find help as well. I was off Klonipin for years
column13: and started taking it again after breast cancer. Unfortunately I am now on a drug that robs me of estrogen for life)and low estrogen was my problem in the beginning. Having to deal with hot flashes and panic again
column14: my doc put me on up to .5 mg per day (half pill as needed). I don't take it every day - the problem seems to follow a monthly calendar. But when I do take it
column15: I'm able to get on with life: no drowsiness
column16: no drugged-up feeling. The doc did try anti-depressants which actually increased my symptoms - which
column17: he said
column18: didn't surprise him. This medication is my rescue
column19: not my daily regime. I resisted taking it even as often as I currently do
column20: but he said I am not refilling my script half as often as I am allowed
column21: so he said I need to think of this in terms of being a rescue companion to the drug that keeps me from having breast cancer again. "

column1: 335$Condition: Panic Disorder$12/2/2010 1:35:22 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I have been stuggling with postpartum depression/anxiety afer my son was born 6 months ago. My anxiety was so bad that i had a breakdown and had to be admited inpatient to a stress center. After a month of being on Xanax as needed and paxil I felt like I was getting worse. I was waking up with severe anxiety and that would turn into a tailspin of crying and extreme panic! Not fun. I finally found a medical professional who knows what she is doing. She is a physiciatric NP. She put me on Klonopin .5mg am/bedtime and she is weaing me off Paxil to the Zoloft. Let's just say I went from histeria on Tuesday morning to calmness upon waking this morning. I am sleeping well also. I expect to be on Klonopin until I am well on Zoloft and then taper off. If you take yourself off of Klonopin by yourself cold turkey of course your going to feeling it. Make sure you are with a physciatrist who knows meds and there side effects and how they will react with you personally. Good luck with everyone else out there

25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$4$5$I have been on this drug for 4 months. I was put on it after having been given a steroid drug post partum to treat a rash. The steroid combined with my post partum state sent my adrenaline out of control and cause anxiety and insomnia. I am seeing one of the top psychiatrists in my city on the subject of anxiety/post partum. This drug has worked well and worked immediately. I mainly wanted to post this because it seems that there is some confusion on here about how to wean. My instructions were to wean myself (as long as I am not having any problems with sleep or anxiety) by a quarter of a tablet (.5mg tablet) not more frequently than every 3 weeks. That is a very SLOW taper. If anyone is on this
column3: make sure you listen to your medical provider on the taper and I doubt you will experience these withdrawal symptoms that some have written. I was taking 3 tablets (1.5 mg) 4 months ago and am now down to 2.25 tablets. That is only dosing myself down by 3 quarters of a tablet in 4 months. This is how to be safe about it. Just be patient and try not to freak out that you are taking this medication. It is just for a season of life and it will end. Be patient.

569$Condition: Panic Disorder$8/24/2009 10:54:44 AM$Reviewer: imaginethat, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$Definitely an effective med for anxiety.  It really helps me focus.  Also significantly reduces my frequent onslaught of overwhelming brain activity that keeps me distracted and unable to focus.  I recently started back on Klonopin after being off for several years.  The only downside is the addictive aspect of this drug.  It is extremely important that you wean yourself off very slowly.  The manufacturer recommends reducing your dose .125 every 3 days.  I would follow that advice if at all possible.  When I was on it before, I just stopped taking it, and was almost hospitilized...having some of the worst out-of-body feelings and physical ailments I've ever felt.  Be careful when stopping use!!!

column1: 592$Condition: Panic Disorder$7/14/2009 7:32:52 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$1$4$"While I agree that Klonopin is very effective
column2: like any benzo-diazapan they also come with severe risks. It is so addictive it is the only drug besides alcohol that can actually kill you if you stop taking it without a doctor supervising.

column1: This can mean that some people who have never abused drugs can end up in a detox center if they have been on a high dose for a lot of years. I do not understand why the drug companies have not found something as effective without the deadly side effects.  It's pretty sad that heroin
column2: cocaine
column3: meth
column4: all illegal drugs do not have the risk of killing you while detoxing but something legal and prescribed does. I do believe there are many people who really need these types of medications but I also believe they are overperscribed as an easy fix to panic attacks. They should be a last resort only and doctors should tell the patients how highly addictive and deadly they can be.  I have honestly seen it ruin lives
column5: and I will honestly admit for all my anger against benzo-diazapans I am still afraid of being off it.I would recommend people to try DBT therapy
column6: it has helped me and I plan on continuing it to help me cope
column7: your phychotherapist/counsler should be able to do this for you. In DBT
column8: patients are not told that their feelings are wrong
column9: but rather that they need to find a more positive way to manage them
column10: They learn mindfulness
column11: stepping back and being conscious of the moment without judging it as good or bad
column12: and other emotion regulating skills
column13: so that their feelings have less influence on their behavior.

column2: coping with situations as they are -- and methods of self-soothing and distraction. It has worked wonders for me!"

35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have taken Clonazepam (Klonopin) for over 4 years.  I initially was started on 0.5mg 2x a day every day for a year and then started taking Lexapro with it.  I continued to take the Clonazepam for another year with the lexapro then decided to wean myself of the clonazepam and just take in on an as needed basis.  It works wonderful for a ""PRN"" (as needed) drug.  I probably take it once or twice every two months and during those times I will take it for 3 or 4 days and then stop and go about my routine till I feel the need for it again.  My anxiety has been greatly under control
column3: it's just every once in a while it creeps up on you and you feel like you can't function.  It's these instances when clonazepam works wonders.  I hope this helps all those with anxiety issues.  I would not recommend this drug on a ""full-time"" basis.  I think it is a great drug to be used in conjunction with another SSRI or SNRI until one that is found that works.  Once the SSRI or SNRI is found to work
column4: the person should wean themselves off this med and then just use it as an as needed medication."

column1: 760$Condition: Panic Disorder$10/28/2008 2:17:07 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$My doc RXed this drug to me 2 years ago after dealing with several personal issues. I have always dealt with chronic panic attacks (15 years or so). I have been prescribed every antidepressant imaginable and nothing worked because I am not depressed. I have extremely high anxiety and panic disorder. Klonopin has helped me so much. I used to not even be able to function at work or even in public due to panic attacks and I am fine now. I have had only a couple of mild attacks in 2 yrs. I recently went to my doc for a follow up and I told her I wanted to decrease my dosage to .25 from .50 and I tried .25 for 2 weeks and couldn't handle the decrease so I went back to .50. I am a troubled sleeper due to high anxiety and I went 2 weeks on little to no sleep. Klonpin is great for insomnia. Doc says if I am ok at .50 I should stay there. I don't want to become physically dependant on this drug to function
column2: but it has helped so much with panic and anxiety. I have no side effects and have never had to increase my dose in 2 yrs. I have always taken .50 1X per day. I'm going to try to decrease to .25mg again and see if I can get past the effects. Overall
column3: I highly recommend this drug over vallium and xanex. I can function fine after taking it and feel great after a full night's sleep.

787$Condition: Other$9/12/2008 3:14:19 AM$Reviewer: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $3$1$4$Given klonopin for chronic headaches, including migraines.  Helpful for a while, but, in time, found anxiety was increasing.  (Have read up on this medication and found this is common.)  The difficult part was STOPPING the medication.  In a word - HORRIFIC!!! I tapered off with my doctor's schedule, very carefully. I NEVER abused the medication, took .5 mg 3xday as prescribed - but when I stopped it, I went through the most horrific withdrawal ever.  21 days of constant, debilitating anxiety - and I had NEVER had a panic attack before!  In my opinion, you can become addicted to this drug WITHOUT abusing it --the physical and emotional withdrawal was evidence of it.  I see this drug as POISON now - I would NEVER take it again.

column2: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$1$5$"This drug greatly helped me deal with panic disorder.  However
column3: my Dr. had me stop taking this drug ""cold turkey"" after a month and a half of use because of suspicion of an alergic reaction.

column1: The withdrawals have been horrible!!  They include psychosis
column2: paranoia
column3: rage
column4: thought disorder
column5: tremors

column1: I strongly recommend against stopping this drug ""cold turkey"".  Since I have had some spare time I have learned that I haven't experienced the worst withdrawal effect of the drug which is seizures.  I feel like I am over the worst part of the witdrawals and I look forward to returning to work.
Please be cautious when using this medication.

893$Condition: Panic Disorder$1/31/2008 1:18:31 AM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I have been taking Klonopin for two years.  I started at .25 three times a day, then after a year, went down to .25 twice a day, and now I take .25 once a day.  Thank god for this drug!  I started having anxiety attacks two years ago, and have only had one in two years (and it was a situation that would cause anyone to feel anxious, so I wasn't too worried - did some Yoga and felt much better).  It worked from the first day I took it.  It works quickly, and for a longer period of time than Xanax and Ativan.  I'm taking Effexor XR as well for anxiety, and it's been a winning combination.  I'm weaning off the klonopin because it makes me sleepy, and the Effexor is working well, but I am really glad this drug was available when I started treatment.  I was really depressed when the attacks started, thinking I'd always be limited because of the fear of having an attack and this worked so well, within a week, I was back to my old self.  I will still take it on an as-needed basis for the occasional bout of anxiety.

902$Condition: Panic Disorder$1/6/2008 6:17:41 PM$Reviewer: Catherine, 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$4$GPD.  Took med for 9-10 years - At the beginning Dr. prescribed 2mg a day...too much, always sleepy. .5mg, once a day worked for me for the time I took it.  The long term affect of the daily dose kept me at an even keel unlike Xanax.  Weaned myself off, with Dr.s knowledge.  Decreased a 1/2 dose every two weeks until I stopped.  Side Effects:  I was sometimes clumsy, fell a couple of times...shattered my kneecap, tripped up stairs and down.  Then I read it adds to Osteo. Am now exercising, eating healthy.  Doing my best to control any panic attacks that I feel may be coming on.  Of course, therapy during that time helped me...deep breathing, subtracting 3 from 100, walking, drinking water (this is during a panic attack.  I have only had the beginning of a couple panic attacks since.  Have been off for two years, now.  But you should have a therapist you can trust, who deals with panic disorder.  Meds can help, but I found that learning to live with a disorder you can try to control through therapy has saved my life.  I'm not saying I will never use Klonopin again, because if I need to I will go back on it.  I loved the calm feeling it gave me.

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $3$2$5$"Used for anxiety
column3: also took wellbutrin for depression.  I have not been on any medication in more a year and am glad to say I have not have any unpleasant side effects. Klonopin did work wonders for anxiety
column4: BUT and this is a huge BUT. Was extremely addicted to this after being on it for a year. Was ""fired"" by my therapist and I went online to learn how to ween myself off of it. I recommend it for anxiety because it works but it's very addictive and made me very tired to the point I would just dose off to sleep. Felt like a junkie. NEVER stop this medication abrubtly.  And if I missed a dose would get the shakes. I emphasize that it does work extremely well but you will become ADDICTED to this medication so be mindful of this. I weened myself off of it SLOWLY and didn't experience any withdrawal symptoms.  I have changed my diet and only eat ORGANIC and whenever I get a little stressed I go the health food store.  They sell homepathic medicine that works just as well for my anxiety and sleepiness without the negative side effects. The organic diet help cut out the intense food cravings I was having. BUT never ever stop taking your medication unless you consult with your physican first.  I don't knock tradional medicine because it helped get me through my rough time when I got divorced and lost my home and everything else I valued and felt like I wanted to end it. I still have ""talk"" therapy and I would still use traditional medication if I need to but I felt I was on klonopin too long and shouldn't have been on it that long. And if it ever gets to point again I would defintely use if it I had to again.  God bless everyone one of you.  Having a mental illness is not easy but just know that it will get better and eventually the sun will come out again. If one medication doesn't help don't give keep trying until you find something that works for you.  Not all medications work the same for everyone but eventually you find something that works for you.  "

column4: I was not informed of just how addictive this drug is. clonazepam helped me for years but after a while made me very suicidal. My doctor and I are now working closely together to taper me off of clonazepam. I have replaced the clonazepam with Librium which is a long lasting benzodiazepine for the slow taper from clonazepam. The taper will take 3 months and then I will have to taper off of the Librium which is much less addictive than the clonazepam. column5: it is to warn anyone of just how addictive clonazepam is and how difficult it is to get off of. Good luck to all and may God bless you!

column2: Adjunct Treatment$8/27/2016 1:09:23 PM$Reviewer: Ray
column3: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$2$4$I was given this medication for severe anxiety associated with schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. I have been on clonazepam for 20 years. The drug helped me for years but ended up making me very suicidal. My physician and I are working closely together now on a very slow taper to get off of clonazepam. The taper requires a replacement drug to get off of it. I am in my third week of the taper replacing the clonazepam with Librium which is another benzodiazepine which is much easier to get off from than clonazepam. This taper will take 3 months. Then I have to be slowly tapered off of the Librium. When I was introduced to clonazepam
column4: I was never told just how addictive it is. While I would never try to interfere with anyone's treatment
column5: I would DEFINATELY caution anyone given clonazepam to be extremely careful because it is extremely addictive and extremely difficult to get off of. My whole reason for making this comment is to let the reader know just what they are getting into by taking this drug. It does work but is extremely addictive. Good luck and may God bless you all!

column2: 45-54 on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$I've used this for over 20 years and. It still helps my RLS about 90% of the time. I'm on 3 a day of the 1 mg and I really think I need mine increased but I don't know if my dr will increase the dosage to the 2 mg. I think the 2 mg in the morning and 2 mg at night would do the trick. That's one pill less a day but it's also 1 mg more a day if it's changed to the 2 mg. I've had RLS since Id was 17 and I've been on carbidopa levodopa for it at first and after about three weeks on that my legs got so bad at night. That medicine made it worse so that's when I changed dr's and was put on the 1 mg 3 times a day. It also works great for my panic or anxiety attacks. I think I having a heart attack when I have those episodes. But if I take a clonazepam it will knock out my chest pains and jaw pain and arm pain in about 20 minutes. It's scary because I'm at the age that I could be having a heart attack and think it's just anxiety.

55-64 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver) $4$3$3$"I am a registered nurse...this drug is extremely addictive..when I read the posts it seems people do not realize that what they are experiencing is withdrawal ..not the need for the drug...(which can be confused) if you go off it..wean yourself off slowly...it should be saved only for panic attacks and used per panic attack..not continuously

column1: any dr. prescribing it for long term use is suspect...really...this is true"

column1: 1043$Condition: Panic Disorder$2/18/2016 2:56:30 AM$Reviewer: 55-64 on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$In 2010 I was prescribed Clonazepam at 1 mg three times a day for severe anxiety/panic attacks. My wife was terminal with cancer since 2005 and was given 3 to 6 months to live after the initial surgery. She had 3 more surgeries and 5 rounds of chemo treatments and after each event I was told 3 to six months. She lived until 2011. I was already being treated for clinical depression (since 1995) and was in terrible shape. My doctor prescribed the Clonazepam and referred me to other options to deal with the anxiety. It really helped when the 'other' non-medical options failed to keep my mind in check. This med actually kept me from killing myself. Unfortunately my condition did not improve with the death of my wife and under close supervision of my doctor I remained on the Clonazepam until January of 2016 when the VA
column2: whom I have been under their care since 2013 when I moved back to my home town
column3: mandated that anyone using Clonazepam and any opiate had to choose to either stay with the Clonazepam or the opiate (I have been on morphine for degenerative discs). You could not use both because of the possibility of developing breathing problems. I had been taking both since 2010 and have not had any problems. The VA prescribed Hydroxyzine Pamoate at 25 mg twice a day. It has not helped my panic issues at all. It just makes me very sleepy and is giving me sinus headaches behind my eyes. I've been on this shit for two weeks and cannot function at all. I'm to damn drowsy and so damn agitated that I haven't left my apartment in a week. I looked up that med on WebMD and found out that the main function of it was for sinus issues
column4: not panic attacks. Note: I can't take antihistamines because of 'another' medical problem I have. I am at my wits end and need to get this resolved before I end up taking that dirt nap.

column2: 35-44 on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $3$4$3$"I have been on this medication for a little over ten years now. I am prescribed three mgs. a day. If I don't take them I will have extreme anxiety and even panic attacks. I found to take as prescribed instead of as needed
column3: it is better to prevent a panic attack rather than have to wait for the medication to work in the middle of an attack! The only reason I gave three stars on effectiveness is due to most of the new generics
column4: they don't seem to be as effective as the older ones such as the Tevas. In my opinion brand name works the best followed by the Tevas then the ""m"" followed by the worst which are the blue ""v"". I'm prescribed the one mg. tablets."

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$"I have been taking 2.5 mg of Clonazpam for 20+ years.  It is an extremely effective medication for panic disorder
column3: general anxiety
column4: and OCD for me.  I am 52 years old and after making planes turn around in the sky and 4 hours in security (pre 9-11) as I was certain my plane would crash
column5: I was prescribed it starting at one mg a day.  After having a panic attack in traffic on the Golden Gate Bridge and getting out of my car to practice my breathing techniques at the rail of the Bridge
column6: with people screaming ""don't jump
column7: it was increased to the level I now take. (Fortunately it was late 1990's and a adorable Dr. In a Porche recognize what was happening and calmed the situation). So no arrest...  Lastly
column8: I want everyone to know
column9: one must tritrat off only with your physicians care and very slowly.  The withdraw symptoms are horrific when I tried once.  Eyes bouncing around shakes sweats etc.  this is drug dependence not addiction.  I also do not believe it to be an acute medication but not sure.  Xanax etc. Give me a hang over feeling the next day or. Headaches mid day.  Drinking and taking this mediation will make a person forget - memory loss.  Just make sure you follow Dr. 's advice to the letter.  Oh yes
column10: and during the withdrawal if too fast
column11: one can actually have seizures- even if you were not prescribed it for any seizure disorder like Epilepsy.  Thank you for reading this."

45-54 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$"Initially this drug seemed safe and useful. I started this drug for anxiety and stress. Unfortunately
column3: I had been extremely misled of its danger. The prescribing doctor eliminated it too quickly and then cowardly denied its correlation to seizures of my jaw radically chomping during the night
column4: severe insomnia
column5: panic attacks
column6: thought process disturbances
column7: and much more miserable consequences. When searching for what was wrong with me so desperately
column8: I went to over twenty doctors that denied such possibility could happen until one that diagnosed me with Post Acute Withdrawal Syndrome (PAWS). Now
column9: not one doctor can or has denied its correlation to my very ailing condition. I've never felt as though I was going to die so many times in my life
column10: and I almost have many times. Had I known about its brain damaging factors
column11: I would never had touched it. Stay away from this drug. Too many doctors are not managing it well and setting people up for misery on top of misery down the road. This will be the cause of your panics
column12: and much worse. My condition is possibly lifelong. It also made it to where I cannot feel pleasure whatsoever and more severe consequences. Thanks docs.

column1: Do your own research and do not trust the loosely prescribing doctors that try to convince you that it is safe for long-term use when it is not.
One well written NYU report link is http://epilepsy.med.nyu.edu/treatment/medications /clonazepam
The Ashton Manual is also a great reference book that most of the world uses except the US.
Do your research before you use this drug! I was stuck on this drug for years. Don't let it happen to you!
Avoid this drug if you can!"

column3: I have found that this drug has been very effective with helping me Cope with the many stressor's that this disease/syndrome presents to the ""silent sufferer's"". After an exhaustive and frustrating search for answers to
column4: ""what exactly do I have and why am I not getting any better?"" After being misdiagnosed and having so called ""Pain Management Specialists"" send me to Psychiatrist's who misdiagnosed me and started and kept me on medications that have terrible side affects such as constant dry mouth
column5: skin rashes
column6: swelling of the tongue (so bad I could not speak)and the list goes on. This PAIN was NOT IN MY HEAD as I was told point blank. RSD/CRPS causes your sympathetic nerves & central nervous system to report REAL NERVE DAMAGE & it reacts to this by causing a ""Hyper-Nerve Stimulation"" which the BRAIN CANNOT HANDLE! Victims of this incurable disease/disorder or syndrome know how this manifests itself physically and this ""Hyper-Nerve Stimulation"" also causes our BRAIN to over-react to common stress ""Hyper-Sensitively""! Forget it if you experience major stress like the loss of a child or parent spouse. That's  when we experience ""flare-ups""! If you are unlucky enough to have foreign surgical objects such as metal screws
column7: plates

column9: BURNING

column12: HEADACHES
column13: MIGRAINES

column16: MUSCLE SPASMS

column18: (PROBLEMS URINATING in my case) are part of the ""Internal Storm"" reacting to the ""External Storm or weather front getting ready to come through. PRAISE THE LORD BECAUSE FINALLY I FOUND A DOCTOR WHO TOOK ONE LOOK AT ME AND IN 15 MINUTES DIAGNOSED ME CORRECTLY AND PRESCRIBED THIS MEDICATION ALONG WITH AN INTRATHECAL PUMP TO DELIVER (YES STRONG NARCOTIC MEDICATION) DIRECTLY INTO MY SPINE THUS AVOIDING OR MINIMIZING THE FURTHER DAMAGE TO MY KIDNEYS

column5: my wife began to become concerrd about my mood swings and suggested that I see a therapist. I did this but it did not help.

column2: symptoms became more frequent and I recognize that I was becoming more like my father concerning his rapid mood swings.

1170$Condition: Panic Disorder$2/21/2013 1:47:33 AM$Reviewer: Martin E, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $4$4$5$After multiple hits to the head from sports and other activities,I developed lasting effects from multiple concussions.I waited a year before medication, with no improvement.Symptoms were sensitivity to light,sound,horrible constant vertigo,visual disturbances,and after all of that I developed an anxiety issue also.At this point, I didn't want to live anymore.I could barely function doing simple daily living tasks, my neuro put me on this med, and it has saved my life. It has helped with so many of the brain problems, and also takes the edge off the anxiety. Dose is .5 in a.m., .25 afternoon, and .5 at night. Cons of this med are withdrawals if I don't take it for a day, and it makes me kind of drowsy.But I can still get through the work day, take a nap afterward, and feel fine. Allows me to live my life, if I have to take a short nap each day in exchange for my life back, that's fine with me. And also, very important, DO NOT drink with it! I did this more than a couple times, and blacked out, not remembering anything, or just bits and pieces.

35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $4$3$5$My pain management doctor gave me an RX for this because my regular muscle relaxer stopped working after being on it for years. I was quite impressed with how much this helped to relax my muscles
column3: however I found that I need to take this at night no later than 7 to 8 hours before I need to be up the following morning. It is really helping better than the muscle relaxer. I am a person who has been on pain meds for over 15 years due to a car accidenct where I was rear ended and have so many things wrong with my back that it is hard to find ways of dealing with the multiple types of pain due to multiple diagnoses. I advise everyone I speak with to not give up and keep fighting for your rights especially when you are dealing with doctors who seem to think they have the manual to your body and know your body better than you do. Keep fighting for what is right for you no matter what anyone else might think. I have been fighting for my own rights for many years and have finally found a team of doctors who seem to listen to what I have to say and seem to understand my frustration of many years of dealing with doctors who don't seem to want to understand and/or deal with my issues. I have even had to deal with doctors and SSI tell me that I am too young to be having all of these issues. Whose right is it to say that anyone is too young to have any type of medical issue regardless of the issue or what caused it or your age. KEEP FIGHTING FOR YOUR RIGHTS AND WHAT IS RIGHT FOR YOU PERSONALLY!!!!!!

column1: If you are on this drug

column1: 1282$Condition: Other$1/12/2012 6:13:00 PM$Reviewer: A word of warning
column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$5$I took clonazepam for 9 years to help with insomnia and anxiety. Although it worked well at first
column3: I needed higher and higher doses over time to achieve the same level of efficacy. This worried me and I decided to stop taking it. Even with a doctor's supervision and a very gradual dose reduction
column4: I still experienced horrible withdrawal symptoms. I would strongly advise against EVER taking this drug
column5: even for a short time. The road to dependence (both physical and mental) is a quick and slippery slope. An outstanding web site to look at is www.benzo.org.uk. You will find out about clonazepam's adverse effects
column6: what withdrawal symptoms can occur
column7: and learn about a time-tested method to get off of it. It's best however
column8: to never take it in the first place.

1295$Condition: Panic Disorder$12/10/2011 2:56:05 AM$Reviewer: Fortressofcomfort, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$4$3$Good but very sedating.  Better for treating insomnia than for in-day anxiety relief.  I prefer Valium during the day; it provides just as good anxiety relief but makes me less drowsy.  10mg Valium is equal to approx 1mg of clonazepam.  I find Valium and Klonipin to not be addictive but found Xanax to be very addictive.  All of thes bentos will build up in your system and can turn you into a zombie quickly, so stick to the prescribed dosage.  I think that is 4mg/day for Klonipin and 40mg/day for Valium.  Summary: if you find it doesn't relieve your anxiety, or is too sedating, ask your doc if you can try Valium.  There's a reason Klonipin is not indicated for anxiety!

column2: it is the most difficult to discontinue and the withdrawal can be extremely intense. Please anyone using this seek a professionals help and guidance to safely come of this Drug. Cerefolin NAC (L-Methylfolate) 7.5mg/day This new generation of vitamin requires a script although not a drug. It's a manipulated form of folic acid 8 times what you get from the GNC version but ALL of it crosses the blood brain barrier whereas OTC versions don't cross at all! That's why ur pee stinks (sorry). It's expensive & insurance won't pay but anyone on SSRI/SNRI's should be on this. It triggers the brains ability to start producing Dopamine
column2: Seratonin and Norepinephrine! If there's nothing to ""reuptake"" then there's no point in using a re-uptake inhibitor (SSRI like Zoloft/Paxil etc...) Everyone should take this nutritional supplement if they take anti-depressants like Effexor
column3: Paxil
column4: Zoloft
column5: Remeron
column6: Cymbalta
column7: Prozac
column8: etc... The company making this curiously makes an almost identical substitute called ""Deplin"" which one thinks competes with the other
column9: but they're both made by Pamlabs. Go to pamlab.com & can get your discount card cuz it's very pricey. It's a miracle vitamin for me. I had a brain injury because of a fall and lost short term memory retention. Dr's said it would take years for it to return. I started taking Cerefolin NAC w/ my Zoloft/Wellbutrin cocktail and it worked immediately. Both Deplin and Cerefolin work the same cuz the main ingredient is L-Methylfolate. Deplin is marketed as something that helps your anti-depressants while Cerefolin is marketed as early stage memory loss or Alzheimer's but it also contains B-12 and another Vitamin which actually makes the Cerefolin NAC a much more effective choice than Deplin for those taking anti-depressants while in either case
column10: I don't see any value in Deplin cuz u'll need Vitamin B supplements as well. Go figure."

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"Have been taking this med for almost 4 years. With originally Effexor and then I was weened off of that. For about 1.5 years (starting 2 years ago) I only used 0.5MG's maybe a half dozen times total. At that point they were no good and it was me dealing with my panic and anxiety attacks. Obout 6 months ago I went back on them because of losing myjob and issues with getting unemployment payments. Was put on Cymbalta for nervous ticks and this has been only used maybe another half dozen times. when i need it it works great. I never got addicted or needed to watch out that I was going to be dependent on it. I can see a life with very few panic attacks on the horizon soon. I can also say that Xanax only worked for a while for me and then didn't.

column1: It is also extremely important for people to make sure that they dont up the doses without help from a doctor first. Also if someone is a drinker this med or any anti anxiety med will have less if any effects.

1408$Condition: Seizures with Irregular Muscle Contractions$12/3/2010 1:41:07 PM$Reviewer: Doctor's Friend, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I have advanced osteoarthritis and several bulging discs which are inoperable.  I did have a laminectomy at L4/5 thirty years ago.  I was experiencing random muscle spasms in my back, right leg and right arm so severe that I was medically retired (total disability) under Social Security. I am now 63 and have been retired about five years.  My last Orthopedic doctor agreed to try and lessen the spasms with an anti anxiety drug, I had learned from a Pharmacist acquaintance that it might be of use.  The relief was verging on spectacular  and a year later when I had moved to another State and entered a Pain Relief Clinic the medication was changed to Clonazepam 2mg twice daily, as needed.  My condition improved so much that 2 mg at bedtime has all but stopped the spasms,  On occasion I may have to use more but I have had no side effects and my quality of life is up 50%.

column2: I was given the usual front-line medications: lexapro
column3: cymbalta
column4: paxil
column5: etc. None of them worked; in fact
column6: the paxil gave me serotonin syndrome
column7: which effectually ended my usage of SSRIs. I had been begging my psychiatrist to prescribe a benzodiazepine throughout my treatment. Finally
column8: he did. I have been taking Clonazepam for some three months now
column9: and I can only say that this drug has saved my life. My debilitating anxiety is gone; I no longer have panic attacks; I have returned to college
column10: and I am generally more happy than I have been for years. The only side-effect I have experienced is a slight drowsiness beginning about an hour before I go to bed.

column2: chronic
column3: debilitating anxiety
column4: and is willing to take this drug AS PRESCRIBED
column5: I can only offer my own experience as a full-hearted endorsement for the responsible use of benzodiazepines (such as Clonazepam). I have experienced no cognitive impairments
column6: as my performance at school can attest to."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$1$5$i started taking these after my first divorce..i took them for 5 years..was not advised that they were highly addictive..had to go without for 3 days because didnt have money to refill..thought i was having a panic attack and actually was going through withdrawals..i started have heart palpatations and severe chest pain..started hallucinating..thought someone was trying to kill me..wanted to jump out a window or walk out in front of a car..anything to stop it..all i could do was push my speed dial not knowing who i was calling and luckily it was my best friend which was 45 min away and i could not even talk..she knew something was wrong and she stayed on the phone and called 911 on her way to my house because she knew she couldnt make it to me in time..they came and i was trying to have a stroke & heart attack at the same time..could not feel my body..had no clue where i was or what i was doing..they said if she had waited to call them til she got to me i would have died from a massive heart attack..i was only 30 when that happened..had to go to hospital and finish going thru detox..to this day
column3: which has been 2 years since that situation
column4: i crave the klonipin..i cant even have them in the house..i have never been addicted or abused any medication..i was terrified and have advised everyone i know to not take them..after i got to the hospital and came out of it
column5: the dr told me that if i ever took one again i would automatically get addictetd again..its a scary felling when u feel like u cant do without a medicine..since then i am great..no adverse side effects of not taking it now..but i did hypnosis & have not had a panic attack in a year & a half..on the internet my boyfriend found a website..instant-hypnosis.com..find the cd for panic attacks..order it..its worth every penny..LORI

19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$4$"It was hard getting my doctor to prescribe a benzo
column3: as I don't have panic disorder but rather an often debilitating social anxiety. Im taking .5mg 2x a day
column4: a very low dose that belies how effective it's been for me.

column1: In social situations I no longer feel like I'm always doing or saying embarrassing or stupid things; my speech and behaviors are no longer inhibited by a perceived omnipresent public scrutiny. When I drink now
column2: it's not a desperate move to ""prep"" myself for a meeting or party. Instead it's for my own enjoyment.

column1: In class I engage the professors regularly (often zealously with my opinions) and have become good friends with some of them. I do find it difficult at first to stay awake when it kicks in during a class
column2: but I had that problem before the clonazepam. Perhaps the only negative aspect is the memory loss
column3: an effect I perceive probably more than most people
column4: being a student. The gaps in information
column5: when they exist
column6: are generally negligible anyway.

column1: I've been on 200mg Zoloft for years now (for the aforementioned anxieties and OCD)
column2: and yet I always felt that my symptoms weren't completely resolved. Though I am aware of the fleeting nature of benzodiazepines' anxiolytic effects
column3: I have come to terms with the possibility of being on such a drug for a long time. Unless it leads to abuse
column4: the benefits far outweigh the costs of klonipin. I am a better person now
column5: because I don't have to live in fear."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$"I was given b/c my neurologist thought I was having break-through simple seizure activity (although I thought I had an anxiety attack or two).  Originally was perscribed 1mg 3x a day.  I only took 1 a day at first and seemed to get a little better after 4-5 days.  Then it was the weekend and I slept through most of that holiday weekend. I thought I should take 2 since I was perscribed 3 a day and after 2 days of that I was groggy all day at work and even fell asleep at work briefly.  After about 9-10 days of taking
column3: I became a disoriented
column4: walking zombie.

column1: After leaving a work party (w/literally 2 sips of wine) at approx. 7:30
column2: I fell asleep on the train ride home (which happened often while taking the medicine but never before in many years of riding the train).  The conductor woke me up and I knew I was a little tired but never thought I was too bad to drive.  I was leaving a (thankfully) nearly empty train station parking lot and blacked out or fell asleep and crashed my car into a cement light fixture.  It knocked me awake and I thought someone hit me and looked around and there was no one in sight.  That was a Thursday
column3: that weekend I tried 3 (as perscribed) and slept most of the weekend and was groggy for a couple days after discontinuing med altogether.  I stopped the med and called the dr but she was on vacation.  A couple weeks later she had me try much lower dose (.125 mg 2 - 3 x day) but it still made me tired but not as bad and didn't seem to notice any real positives."

column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$2$4$"Clonazepam worked very well the first week. I could sleep for 6 hrs and not wake up in a state of panic with a racing heartbeat.  My anxiety symptoms were calmer too.  But after a week I started feeling general anxiety about situations where I normally have just a little uneasiness.   As the 2nd week went on.. my anxiety grew stronger and stronger.. but when I hit a state of panic attack the drug kicks in and I feel calmer and don't feel the emotional effects of the panic attack.  I do have the racing heartbeat though.. so I take a beta blocker (propanolol) to help slow it down a bit. I was still able to sleep. Until two nights ago when my anxiety about being able to get to my doctors appointment on time woke me up too early.   then I spoke with the doctor about my symptoms and he said I was having daily anxiety withdrawal as the drug started to wear off the next morning.  He switched me to tazepam but the pharmacy wants 430 dollars for 60 pills... who can afford that? The doctor also put me on Citalopram 10 mg yesterday for 6 days and then go to 20 mgs after that.  I took my first pill last night and woke up early so I have insomnia and feel very tired and am subject to anxiety still.  I would like to get off clonazepam soon so I can get some sleep and not feel so exhausted and vulnerable.

column1: For short term use.. 2 to 3 weeks
column2: this drug is okay. For long term use.. I suggest you use something else."

column1: 1782$Condition: Panic Disorder$3/19/2009 10:57:56 PM$Reviewer: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient) $5$5$5$It is hard to explain. One day at work I FELT LIKE I WAS HAVING A STOKE. I was 35 years old.I HAD CHILLS
column2: RIGHT SIDE WAS NUMB. I ASKED MY BOSS TO CALL AN AMBULANCE SHE WOULD NOT SO I DROVE MYSELF TO HOSPITAL. As I was walking to my CAR MY FEET FELT RUBBERY BUT I MADE IT TO MY CAR. AT HOSPITAL THEY DID AN MRI THE NEXT DAY ALL WAS FINE.As time went on I would have this feeling in the lower chest where the rib cage comes together. I JUST COULD NOT FUNCTION. I would have to go and lay down and a few hours later I would be ok. I took many trips to er with same results. They could find nothing wrong.I had all the tests MRI
column3: CAT SCAN
column4: BLOOD WORK
column5: CERTAIN URINE TESTS
column6: EKG
column7: EEG
column8: STREss TEST ALL WAS GOOD. SO i TRIED ANOTHER DOCTOR SAME RESULTS. Finally a doctor sent me to a psychiatrist. He put me on .5 mg klonopin one at bedtime. That was it I was cured. But I worry about dependency. So I stopped taking it after a month and the feeling in chest came back
column9: my legs would feel weird and I just felt like I was going to pass out. I am happy go lucky I do not understand. But another psychiatrist said it is how my body handles stress even though you do not realize you are stressed. so he put me on clonazepam .5 mg one a day but i only take as needed. I have been taking for 10 years but the key is take as needed. I take half .5 mg pill as needed. I use about 60 pills a year taking a half pill when needed.That would be .25 mg. Which would be 120 doses a year.The doctor says take one pill a day but I will not afraid of dependency so i take as needed maybe 3x  aweek  it varies. I have not had a trip to ER since. I still feel stressed at times but the pill seems to do the trick. If i took one .25 every day maybe I would be fine all the time but I believe I would have to up the doseage as time went by and eventually it would no longer work. The doctor said he cannot see how .25 when needed works but if it does ok. Believe me it works.

1963$Condition: Panic Disorder$6/3/2008 7:57:19 PM$Reviewer: eravenheart, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $3$3$2$I started on Lorazepam but an ER doc decided that it was not working enough because it didn't last long enough.  I ended up on 2mg of Clonazepam a day.  I took that for about 2 weeks after almost 3 months on Lorazepam.  A new pcp decided to cut my dosage down to .25mg a day all at once.  The withdrawal started immediately.  It has not been too bad yet but I'm only in my 5th day.  On the second day I just stopped taking it altogether since it was doing nothing for me anyway (the withdrawal symptoms create their own anxiety).  However
column2: while on this drug
column3: I did not have a single panic attack.  I did experience moderate to severe dizziness at times (especially on standing rapidly or moving my head too quickly) and a severe loss of appetite.  I thought that bad at first but discovered that eating very small portions more often allowed me to gain my appetite back.  Since I was overweight to begin with
column4: this turned out to be good as I have lost nearly 20 pounds.  I have read from others that they take doses only when they feel a full panic attack coming on rather than routinely to combat constant anxiety.  I will be attempting that if I actually have a full blown panic attack.  I'm close a lot of the time right now but know that much of it is withdrawal.  I would recommend that
column5: if you have been prescribed this medication for routine
column6: daily dosage that you talk with your doctor about changing to an ""as needed"" drug to avoid serious withdrawal symptoms.  Also
column7: avoid alcohol when you've taken this.  It really knocks me for a loop.  All in all
column8: it is a decent drug but the addiction factor really needs to be considered before taking.  Good luck to you and all of us dealing with this medication."

column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$"I take Klonopin (1.5 mg) and Lexapro (20 mg) to treat anxiety and ADD-HI (hyperactivity/impulsivity). I take them at night to make sure that I can sleep because I'm usally ""wired"" from the effects of my ADD-HI.  The Klonopin itself is a life saver because it calms me down enough that I can get a decent night's sleep.  The only thing unfortunate about it is that I am sometimes drowsy if I don't get at least 8 hours of sleep (as with any sleeping pill).  I don't take it if I've been drinking or have taken Benadryl for my allergies so I have never had withdrawal sympotoms or adverse side effects.  I tend to take a ""vacation"" from the Klonopin some weekends as to prevent a negative interaction with alcohol.  This drug is very effective if you use it properly."

45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$I've was prescribed Clonazepam by my Primary Physician; my depression had advanced to a somewaht mild form of Bipolarism.  Given the the dosage prescribed (.5mg)
column3: I didn't think it was going to work
column4: given that I was taking 40 mg of Prozac.  Upon taking the first pill I noticed a different within an hour; I slept liek a baby for the first time in years.  When I work up
column5: I felt such a sense of calm that it pleased me--yet frighted me-at the same time.  I went to work for the FIRST TIME with a PLEASANT DISOPSITON; I didn't need to get two martinis at lunchtime in order to get through the rest of the day.  I wasn't SNAPPING OFF at my family that evening. Granted
column6: by the FOURTH TABLET I began feeling quite lightheaded
column7: walking somewhat wobbly.  I ate a good breakfast and some fruit and relaxed.  Of all the meds I have taken over the past eleven years
column8: I have found this one to be working (so far so good). As for the possibility of becoming addicted to the meds
column9: I been through enough enough addictions to such meds that I force my self to rise above it--because I want to get better.  I don't feel I'm in the place to recommend this to anyone; what can be one person's Nirvana can be another person's Purgatory. If you have a good doctor (Primary
column10: Psycologist
column11: other) whom you feel you can trust and will prescribe a med that will work for you (and only YOU)
column12: go for it.  But always remember and don't ever forget--the meds are'nt going to solve whatever problems triggering your symptoms--YOU ARE.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $1$1$1$  This is one of the most dangerous drugs in the world and I can't understand how any doctor in good conscience could ever prescribe it for anyone.  I am so sorry I ever took that first pill...I began having problems from the start but didn't think it was the drug and the doctor didn't seem to know what I was experiencing was coming from the drug either.  I would get extremely lightheaded
column3: so much so I could barely function; all I wanted to do was lay around because I had no energy or interest in doing anything
column4: even the most simple things became difficult to do. It also numbs you emotionally and my mind and memory have been dulled.  Take anything but this drug.  No one explained to me that this drug is a class that is not like antidepressants
column5: but it's a hynotic drug.  It should be used ONLY for very severe cases of panic or seizures...not for anxiety like I have and even then for only short periods of time...two-4 weeks. Please don't let anyone talk you into taking this drug.  You willl find it's a living hell if you ever want to come off of it.  From the things I have read
column6: everyone who has tried to come off of it has had horrible experiences with withdrawal due to your whole nervous system being dependent upon it.  Your body is no longer able to function normally.  Your brain no longer manufactures its own hormones because this drug has taken over.  It will take a long time for your brain to begin to make it's own again.  Other organs are affected
column7: also.  I would like to convince the whole world of the dangers of this drug and tell them that any doctor who puts you on it
column8: find another doctor.

2098$Condition: Panic Disorder$9/18/2007 2:10:37 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$This medication was given to me by my PCP, most likely based on poor judgement. It instantly threw me into a heavy depression, and worsened my condition. I was unnable to move, or get out of bed, or go to work or eat for five days. I felt hopeless, listless, and chronicly sleepy/drowsy. I even took a Provigil one of those days in an attempt to stay awake and fell asleep anyways. I quickly decided to discontinue the use of this medication. It was prescribed to me for anxiety and I highly recommend that if your PCP prescribes this to you for that reason, take it as needed as opposed to the dosing I was instructed to follow which was two 0.5 mg pills daily, in addition to 20 mg Lexapro which I am considering coming off of as well. --Not to mention, none of this helped to ease my anxiety.
